RSRC_SHOULDER_001.text: Does your shoulder pain come on with physical exertion, climbing stairs, or emotional stress?
RSRC_SHOULDER_001.clinical_note: CARDIAC RED FLAG - exertion-related pain is classic angina

RSRC_SHOULDER_002.text: Do you have chest tightness, pressure, or heaviness along with your shoulder pain?
RSRC_SHOULDER_002.clinical_note: CARDIAC RED FLAG - chest symptoms with shoulder pain = urgent

RSRC_SHOULDER_003.text: Do you experience shortness of breath, sweating, or nausea with your shoulder pain?
RSRC_SHOULDER_003.clinical_note: CARDIAC RED FLAG - autonomic symptoms suggest MI

RSRC_SHOULDER_004.text: Does your pain spread to your jaw, inner arm, or across your chest?
RSRC_SHOULDER_004.clinical_note: CARDIAC RED FLAG - radiation pattern of cardiac pain

RSRC_SHOULDER_005.text: When you press firmly on the painful area, does it reproduce your exact symptoms?
RSRC_SHOULDER_005.clinical_note: Palpation reproducing pain = LOCAL; NOT reproducing = think cardiac/visceral

RSRC_SHOULDER_006.text: Do you have a history of heart disease, high blood pressure, diabetes, or high cholesterol?
RSRC_SHOULDER_006.clinical_note: Cardiac risk factors increase suspicion for referred cardiac pain

RSRC_SHOULDER_007.text: Is your pain constant and progressively getting worse over weeks/months, even at rest?
RSRC_SHOULDER_007.clinical_note: RED FLAG - constant progressive pain = think malignancy

RSRC_SHOULDER_008.text: Do you have severe night pain that wakes you and is NOT relieved by changing position?
RSRC_SHOULDER_008.clinical_note: RED FLAG - unrelenting night pain = think malignancy/infection

RSRC_SHOULDER_009.text: Have you had unexplained weight loss (>10 lbs) in the past few months?
RSRC_SHOULDER_009.clinical_note: RED FLAG - unexplained weight loss = malignancy screen

RSRC_SHOULDER_010.text: Do you have a history of smoking or are you a current smoker?
RSRC_SHOULDER_010.clinical_note: Smoking history + shoulder pain = screen for Pancoast tumor

RSRC_SHOULDER_011.text: Do you have weakness in your hand muscles (difficulty with grip) or drooping eyelid on the same side?
RSRC_SHOULDER_011.clinical_note: RED FLAG - Horner syndrome or T1 weakness = Pancoast tumor

referral_questions._comment_cervical: ===== CERVICAL SPINE SCREENING (Priority 2 - 50% of shoulder pain!) =====

RSRC_SHOULDER_012.text: Does moving your neck (looking up, down, or turning) change or worsen your shoulder symptoms?
RSRC_SHOULDER_012.clinical_note: PATHOGNOMONIC for cervical referral - neck movement affecting shoulder = cervical source

RSRC_SHOULDER_013.text: Does raising your arm above your head actually RELIEVE your shoulder/arm pain?
RSRC_SHOULDER_013.clinical_note: PATHOGNOMONIC - Shoulder Abduction Sign = cervical radiculopathy (reduces nerve root tension)

RSRC_SHOULDER_014.text: Do your symptoms travel below your elbow into your forearm or hand?
RSRC_SHOULDER_014.clinical_note: Symptoms below elbow = likely cervical radiculopathy (dermatomal distribution)

RSRC_SHOULDER_015.text: Do you have numbness or tingling in your fingers?

RSRC_SHOULDER_015B.text: Which fingers have the numbness or tingling?
RSRC_SHOULDER_015B.clinical_note: Dermatomal: Thumb/Index=C6; Middle=C7; Ring/Little=C8 or TOS

RSRC_SHOULDER_016.text: Do you have neck stiffness or pain?
RSRC_SHOULDER_016.clinical_note: Associated neck symptoms increase cervical probability

RSRC_SHOULDER_017.text: Does keeping your neck in one position (e.g., at computer) make your symptoms worse?
RSRC_SHOULDER_017.clinical_note: Sustained cervical posture worsening = cervical source

RSRC_SHOULDER_018.text: Does tilting your head away from the painful shoulder give you relief?
RSRC_SHOULDER_018.clinical_note: Head tilt relief = reduces nerve root tension = cervical

RSRC_SHOULDER_019.text: Do you have burning or electric/shooting pain down your arm?

RSRC_SHOULDER_020.text: Does keeping your arm raised overhead for a while (like blow-drying hair) cause arm fatigue, numbness, or color changes?
RSRC_SHOULDER_020.clinical_note: Arm fatigue/symptoms with sustained overhead = Thoracic Outlet Syndrome

RSRC_SHOULDER_021.text: Do you notice your hand or arm changing color (pale, blue) or feeling cold?

RSRC_SHOULDER_022.text: Do you have swelling in your hand or arm?
RSRC_SHOULDER_022.clinical_note: Hand/arm swelling = venous TOS or lymphatic obstruction

RSRC_SHOULDER_024.text: Does eating fatty or greasy foods make your pain worse?
RSRC_SHOULDER_024.clinical_note: Right shoulder + worse with fatty food = gallbladder referral

RSRC_SHOULDER_025.text: Do you have pain in your upper right abdomen (under ribs on the right)?
RSRC_SHOULDER_025.clinical_note: RUQ pain with right shoulder = gallbladder referral

RSRC_SHOULDER_026.text: Do you have stiffness or pain between your shoulder blades or upper back?

RSRC_SHOULDER_027.text: Do you have difficulty or pain when twisting your upper body (like looking over your shoulder while driving)?
RSRC_SHOULDER_027.clinical_note: Limited thoracic rotation = thoracic spine referral

RSRC_SHOULDER_028.text: Can you reach your arm behind your back (like tucking in a shirt or doing up a bra)?
RSRC_SHOULDER_028.clinical_note: Difficulty reaching behind = frozen shoulder or rotator cuff

RSRC_SHOULDER_029.text: Even when someone else tries to move your arm for you (completely relaxed), is the movement still very limited?
RSRC_SHOULDER_029.clinical_note: PATHOGNOMONIC - Passive ROM restricted = FROZEN SHOULDER (not rotator cuff)

RSRC_SHOULDER_030.text: Is turning your arm outward (like showing your palm facing forward) particularly difficult?
RSRC_SHOULDER_030.clinical_note: External rotation most limited = classic frozen shoulder pattern

RSRC_SHOULDER_031.clinical_note: Diabetes is major risk factor for frozen shoulder (5x risk)

RSRC_SHOULDER_032.text: Does your shoulder pain occur in a specific arc when raising your arm (roughly between waist and shoulder height)?

RSRC_SHOULDER_033.text: Does overhead activity (reaching up, washing hair) make your pain worse?
RSRC_SHOULDER_033.clinical_note: Overhead worsening = impingement or rotator cuff

RSRC_SHOULDER_034.text: Is your pain mainly at the front or side of your shoulder (not top or back)?
RSRC_SHOULDER_034.clinical_note: Anterior/lateral pain = impingement, rotator cuff, or biceps

RSRC_SHOULDER_035.text: Do you have weakness when lifting your arm up or out to the side?
RSRC_SHOULDER_035.clinical_note: True weakness with elevation = rotator cuff tear (vs C5 radiculopathy)

RSRC_SHOULDER_036.text: Can you hold your arm out to the side (at shoulder height) without it dropping down?
RSRC_SHOULDER_036.clinical_note: Positive Drop Arm test (arm falls) = rotator cuff tear

RSRC_SHOULDER_037.text: Do you have weakness when rotating your arm outward (external rotation)?
RSRC_SHOULDER_037.clinical_note: External rotation weakness = infraspinatus/teres minor involvement

RSRC_SHOULDER_038.text: Does your shoulder pain wake you at night, especially when lying on that side?
RSRC_SHOULDER_038.clinical_note: Night pain lying on shoulder = rotator cuff tear common feature

RSRC_SHOULDER_039.text: Did your shoulder problem start after a specific injury or fall?
RSRC_SHOULDER_039.clinical_note: Traumatic onset = acute tear, fracture, or dislocation

RSRC_SHOULDER_040.text: Is your pain right at the TOP of your shoulder (at the bony point where shoulder meets collarbone)?
RSRC_SHOULDER_040.clinical_note: Top of shoulder pain = AC joint

RSRC_SHOULDER_041.text: Does reaching across your body (like scratching opposite shoulder) cause pain at the top of your shoulder?
RSRC_SHOULDER_041.clinical_note: PATHOGNOMONIC - Cross-body pain = AC joint pathology

RSRC_SHOULDER_042.text: Do you feel clicking, catching, or popping in your shoulder?
RSRC_SHOULDER_042.clinical_note: Clicking/catching = labral tear or SLAP lesion

RSRC_SHOULDER_043.text: Does your shoulder feel like it might slip out of place or feel unstable?
RSRC_SHOULDER_043.clinical_note: Instability feeling = labral tear or shoulder instability

RSRC_SHOULDER_044.text: Have you ever had your shoulder dislocate (come out of joint)?
RSRC_SHOULDER_044.clinical_note: History of dislocation = instability, likely Bankart lesion

RSRC_SHOULDER_045.text: Do you participate in overhead throwing sports (baseball, tennis, volleyball)?
RSRC_SHOULDER_045.clinical_note: Overhead athlete = higher risk for SLAP tears

RSRC_SHOULDER_046.text: Do you have a 'dead arm' feeling after certain movements?
RSRC_SHOULDER_046.clinical_note: Dead arm = instability or SLAP lesion in athletes

RSRC_SHOULDER_047.text: Is there tenderness at the front of your shoulder in the groove where biceps tendon runs?

RSRC_SHOULDER_048.text: Does resisting elbow bending (bicep curl motion) cause shoulder pain?
RSRC_SHOULDER_048.clinical_note: Pain with resisted elbow flexion = biceps tendinopathy

RSRC_SHOULDER_049.text: Did your shoulder pain come on gradually over months/years?

RSRC_SHOULDER_050.text: Do you feel grinding or crunching (crepitus) when moving your shoulder?
RSRC_SHOULDER_050.clinical_note: Crepitus = glenohumeral OA or AC joint arthritis

RSRC_SHOULDER_051.text: Have you had a previous significant shoulder injury?

RSRC_SHOULDER_054.text: Is your dominant arm the one affected?
RSRC_SHOULDER_054.clinical_note: Dominant arm = overuse/rotator cuff; Non-dominant = consider other causes

RSRC_KNEE_001.text: Do you have any pain or discomfort in your groin area or front of your hip?
RSRC_KNEE_001.clinical_note: Pathognomonic for hip referral to knee

RSRC_KNEE_002.text: Do you have stiffness or difficulty with activities like putting on socks/shoes or getting in/out of a car?

RSRC_KNEE_003.text: Do you have any lower back pain, or does bending your back affect your knee symptoms?

RSRC_KNEE_004.text: Does your knee lock, catch, or give way?

RSRC_KNEE_005.text: Is there visible swelling in your knee?

RSRC_HIP_001.text: Is your pain located in your groin or the front of your hip (not the side or back)?
RSRC_HIP_001.clinical_note: Groin pain = true hip joint. Side/back pain often referred.

RSRC_HIP_002.text: Does bending forward or backward at your lower back change your hip symptoms?

RSRC_HIP_003.text: Do you have lower back pain or stiffness along with your hip symptoms?

RSRC_HIP_004.text: Does your pain extend below your knee into your lower leg or foot?

RSRC_HIP_005.text: Is your pain located just below your belt line on one side (near the dimple of your lower back)?

RSRC_LBP_001.text: Do you have any numbness, tingling, or weakness in your SADDLE AREA (inner thighs, buttocks, genitals)?
RSRC_LBP_001.clinical_note: CAUDA EQUINA RED FLAG - Surgical emergency if positive

RSRC_LBP_002.text: Have you had any NEW problems with bladder control (inability to urinate, incontinence, or not knowing when you need to go)?
RSRC_LBP_002.clinical_note: CAUDA EQUINA RED FLAG - Surgical emergency if positive

RSRC_LBP_003.text: Have you had any NEW problems with bowel control (incontinence or not feeling when you need to go)?
RSRC_LBP_003.clinical_note: CAUDA EQUINA RED FLAG - Surgical emergency if positive

RSRC_LBP_004.text: Do you have weakness in BOTH legs, or progressive weakness getting worse over days?
RSRC_LBP_004.clinical_note: CAUDA EQUINA RED FLAG - Bilateral motor deficit

RSRC_LBP_005.text: Have you ever been diagnosed with cancer?
RSRC_LBP_005.clinical_note: MALIGNANCY RED FLAG - History of cancer + back pain

RSRC_LBP_006.text: Have you had unexplained weight loss recently (more than 10 lbs / 5kg without trying)?
RSRC_LBP_006.clinical_note: MALIGNANCY RED FLAG - Unexplained weight loss

RSRC_LBP_007.text: Do you have fever, chills, or night sweats along with your back pain?
RSRC_LBP_007.clinical_note: INFECTION RED FLAG - Fever + back pain = possible spinal infection

RSRC_LBP_008.text: Have you had a recent spinal injection, surgery, or procedure?

RSRC_LBP_009.text: Do you use intravenous drugs, or have a weakened immune system (HIV, chemotherapy, immunosuppressants)?
RSRC_LBP_009.clinical_note: INFECTION risk factor - IV drug use/immunosuppression

RSRC_LBP_010.text: Did your back pain start after a significant trauma (fall, car accident)?

RSRC_LBP_011.text: Do you have osteoporosis, or have you taken steroid medications (like prednisone) for more than 3 months?

RSRC_LBP_012.text: Is the pain constant, severe at night, and NOT relieved by rest or position change?
RSRC_LBP_012.clinical_note: RED FLAG - Night pain unrelieved by rest suggests malignancy/infection

RSRC_LBP_013.text: Is your leg pain WORSE than your back pain?
RSRC_LBP_013.clinical_note: Pathognomonic for radiculopathy - leg > back pain

RSRC_LBP_014.text: Does your pain travel down your leg in a specific pattern (e.g., back of thigh to calf, or side of leg to foot)?

RSRC_LBP_015.text: Do you have numbness, tingling, or pins and needles in your leg or foot?
RSRC_LBP_015.clinical_note: Neurological symptoms suggest nerve root involvement

RSRC_LBP_016.text: Is your pain worse when sitting, bending forward, or lifting?

RSRC_LBP_017.text: Is your pain worse when coughing, sneezing, or straining?
RSRC_LBP_017.clinical_note: Valsalva maneuver increases disc pressure - suggests disc pathology

RSRC_LBP_018.text: Is your pain worse when standing up straight, arching backward, or walking?

RSRC_LBP_019.text: Do you get leg pain, heaviness, or weakness when WALKING that is relieved when you SIT DOWN or lean forward?

RSRC_LBP_020.text: Can you walk further when leaning on a shopping cart or walking uphill than on flat ground?
RSRC_LBP_020.clinical_note: Shopping cart sign = spinal stenosis (flexion opens spinal canal)

RSRC_LBP_021.text: Do you have symptoms in BOTH legs when walking (not just one)?
RSRC_LBP_021.clinical_note: Bilateral symptoms = stenosis or central disc. Unilateral = radiculopathy

RSRC_LBP_022.text: Is your pain mainly on ONE SIDE of your lower back (not central)?
RSRC_LBP_022.clinical_note: Unilateral = facet, SI joint, or unilateral muscle. Central = disc, stenosis

RSRC_LBP_023.text: Do you have pain that refers to your buttock or back of thigh but does NOT go below the knee?
RSRC_LBP_023.clinical_note: Referred pain stopping above knee = facet, SI, muscle (not true radiculopathy)

RSRC_LBP_024.text: Can you point to a specific tender spot in your lower back just beside the spine?
RSRC_LBP_024.clinical_note: Paraspinal tenderness = muscle strain or facet

RSRC_LBP_025.text: Do you have muscle spasm or tightness in your lower back that you can feel?
RSRC_LBP_025.clinical_note: Muscle spasm common with strain but also protective in disc/facet

RSRC_LBP_026.text: Did your pain start suddenly after lifting, twisting, or a specific activity?
RSRC_LBP_026.clinical_note: Sudden onset with activity = disc, muscle strain

RSRC_LBP_027.text: Can you point with ONE FINGER to where your pain is located (just below the dimple of your back)?
RSRC_LBP_027.clinical_note: Fortin finger test - pointing below PSIS = SI joint dysfunction

RSRC_LBP_028.text: Is your pain worse when going from sitting to standing, or with single-leg activities (stairs, getting in car)?
RSRC_LBP_028.clinical_note: SI joint aggravated by asymmetric loading

RSRC_LBP_029.text: Is your pain worse when rolling over in bed or lying on the affected side?
RSRC_LBP_029.clinical_note: Rolling in bed pain = SI joint

RSRC_LBP_030.text: Are you pregnant, recently given birth, or experiencing pelvic/hip changes?
RSRC_LBP_030.clinical_note: Pregnancy/postpartum = high risk for SI joint dysfunction

RSRC_LBP_031.text: Do you have pain or stiffness in your GROIN?
RSRC_LBP_031.clinical_note: PATHOGNOMONIC for hip joint - groin pain = hip not spine

RSRC_LBP_032.text: Do you have difficulty putting on socks/shoes or tying shoelaces due to hip stiffness (not back pain)?
RSRC_LBP_032.clinical_note: Hip-spine syndrome - hip OA presenting as LBP

RSRC_LBP_033.text: Do you limp when walking, or have difficulty getting in/out of a car?
RSRC_LBP_033.clinical_note: Hip symptoms masquerading as back pain

RSRC_LBP_034.text: How long does your morning stiffness last?

RSRC_LBP_035.text: Does your pain IMPROVE with exercise and movement (rather than rest)?
RSRC_LBP_035.clinical_note: PATHOGNOMONIC for inflammatory back pain (AS/axial SpA)

RSRC_LBP_036.text: Does your pain get WORSE with rest (not better)?
RSRC_LBP_036.clinical_note: Pain worse with rest = inflammatory back pain

RSRC_LBP_037.text: Does your pain wake you up in the SECOND HALF of the night (not just trouble falling asleep)?
RSRC_LBP_037.clinical_note: 2nd half of night waking = inflammatory back pain (AS criterion)

RSRC_LBP_038.text: Do you have ALTERNATING buttock pain (sometimes left, sometimes right)?
RSRC_LBP_038.clinical_note: Alternating buttock pain = inflammatory SI joint involvement (AS)

RSRC_LBP_039.text: How old were you when your back pain FIRST started?
RSRC_LBP_039.clinical_note: Onset <45 = inflammatory SpA criteria; >50 = cancer/OA risk

RSRC_LBP_040.text: Has your back pain been present for more than 3 months?
RSRC_LBP_040.clinical_note: >3 months = chronic; also inflammatory SpA criterion

RSRC_LBP_041.text: Did your back pain come on gradually (insidious onset) rather than suddenly?
RSRC_LBP_041.clinical_note: Insidious onset = inflammatory SpA; sudden = disc, fracture

RSRC_LBP_042.text: Do you have a family history of ankylosing spondylitis, psoriasis, or inflammatory bowel disease?
RSRC_LBP_042.clinical_note: Family history increases inflammatory SpA likelihood

RSRC_LBP_043.text: Do you have pain in your FLANK (side of your back below the ribs)?
RSRC_LBP_043.clinical_note: Flank pain = kidney (renal colic, infection, stone)

RSRC_LBP_044.text: Do you have urinary symptoms (burning, frequency, blood in urine, difficulty urinating)?
RSRC_LBP_044.clinical_note: Urinary symptoms + back pain = renal pathology

RSRC_LBP_045.text: Is your pain colicky (comes and goes in waves of severe pain)?

RSRC_LBP_046.text: Do you have abdominal pain, especially in the upper abdomen/stomach area that radiates to your back?
RSRC_LBP_046.clinical_note: Epigastric pain radiating to back = pancreatitis, AAA, ulcer

RSRC_LBP_047.text: Do you have nausea, vomiting, or is your pain worse after eating?
RSRC_LBP_047.clinical_note: GI symptoms with back pain = visceral cause

RSRC_LBP_048.text: Can you feel a pulsating mass in your abdomen, or have you been told you have an enlarged aorta?
RSRC_LBP_048.clinical_note: AAA RED FLAG - Pulsating abdominal mass is emergency

RSRC_LBP_049.text: Do you have cardiovascular risk factors (smoking, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, diabetes)?
RSRC_LBP_049.clinical_note: Vascular risk factors increase AAA likelihood

RSRC_LBP_050.clinical_note: >50 = cancer risk; >70 = fracture risk; >65 male = AAA risk

RSRC_LBP_051.text: Is there a tender spot directly over your spine when pressing on the bones (spinous processes)?
RSRC_LBP_051.clinical_note: Midline bony tenderness = fracture or infection

RSRC_LBP_052.text: Have conservative treatments (rest, medication, physio) failed to help after 6+ weeks?
RSRC_LBP_052.clinical_note: Failure of conservative treatment = needs further investigation

RSRC_LBP_053.text: Do you feel generally unwell, tired, or have had a recent infection elsewhere in your body?
RSRC_LBP_053.clinical_note: Systemic symptoms suggest infection or malignancy

RSRC_LBP_054.clinical_note: Female = osteoporosis/fracture risk; Male >65 = AAA risk

RSRC_NECK_001.text: Do you have stiffness or pain between your shoulder blades or upper back?
RSRC_NECK_001.clinical_note: Thoracic spine major contributor to neck pain

RSRC_NECK_002.text: Do you have any jaw pain, clicking, or do you grind your teeth?
RSRC_NECK_002.clinical_note: TMJ dysfunction contributes to neck pain

RSRC_NECK_003.text: Is your neck pain worse after prolonged sitting or computer work?

RSRC_NECK_004.text: Do you experience dizziness, visual disturbances, or difficulty speaking when moving your neck?
RSRC_NECK_004.clinical_note: VERTEBRAL ARTERY RED FLAG - Do not manipulate neck

RSRC_ELBOW_001.text: Does moving your neck change your elbow symptoms?

RSRC_ELBOW_002.text: Do you have tingling in your thumb or index finger?

RSRC_ELBOW_003.text: Is there a specific tender spot on the outside or inside of your elbow?

RSRC_ELBOW_004.text: Does your elbow pain increase with gripping or twisting (like opening a jar)?

RSRC_ELBOW_005.text: Do you have tingling in your ring finger or little finger?

RSRC_ANKLE_001.text: Do you have any lower back pain, or pain traveling down your buttock or leg?
RSRC_ANKLE_001.clinical_note: Key discriminator for lumbar referral vs local ankle

RSRC_ANKLE_002.text: How did your ankle pain start?

options.text: Twisted inward / rolled over outside of foot
Twisted outward / rolled over inside of foot
Foot was planted and leg/body rotated outward

RSRC_ANKLE_002.clinical_note: Critical: Inversion=ATFL/CFL, External rotation=High ankle (syndesmosis), Eversion=medial, Gradual=tendinopathy/referred

RSRC_ANKLE_003.text: Where exactly is your ankle pain located?

options.text: Back of the ankle / Achilles area
Above the ankle, between the two leg bones

RSRC_ANKLE_003.clinical_note: Critical first-level discriminator for ankle region

RSRC_ANKLE_003B.text: You said the outside of your ankle - where exactly on the outside is most tender?

options.text: In FRONT of the ankle bone (towards toes)
Directly ON the ankle bone itself

RSRC_ANKLE_003B.clinical_note: CRITICAL: Anterior=ATFL, Inferior=CFL, Posterior=Peroneal, On bone=Fracture (Ottawa)

RSRC_ANKLE_004.text: Is your pain worse when pushing off (like going up on your toes or climbing stairs)?

RSRC_ANKLE_005.text: Is your ankle stiff and painful first thing in the morning, then improves as you walk?
RSRC_ANKLE_005.clinical_note: Classic for Achilles tendinopathy - distinguishes from acute injury

RSRC_ANKLE_006.text: Do you have numbness or tingling mainly on the sole/bottom of your foot?
RSRC_ANKLE_006.clinical_note: Pathognomonic for tarsal tunnel syndrome - distinguish from L5/S1 radiculopathy

RSRC_ANKLE_007.text: Do you have numbness or tingling on the top of your foot or in your toes following a specific pattern? (e.g., big toe area vs outer small toes)
RSRC_ANKLE_007.clinical_note: Dermatomal patterns: Big toe/dorsum = L5; Lateral foot/small toes = S1

RSRC_ANKLE_008.text: Are your symptoms worse at night or do they wake you from sleep?
RSRC_ANKLE_008.clinical_note: Night symptoms suggest tarsal tunnel or peripheral neuropathy

RSRC_ANKLE_009.text: Does your calf or ankle pain come on when walking and go away when you stop and rest?
RSRC_ANKLE_009.clinical_note: PAD RED FLAG - Claudication pattern requires vascular assessment

RSRC_ANKLE_010.text: Are your feet often cold, or have you noticed hair loss on your lower legs?

RSRC_ANKLE_011.text: Is your calf swollen, warm, or red compared to the other side?
RSRC_ANKLE_011.clinical_note: DVT RED FLAG - Urgent vascular assessment required

RSRC_ANKLE_012.text: Have you had recent prolonged travel (flight/car), surgery, or been immobile for an extended period?
RSRC_ANKLE_012.clinical_note: DVT risk factor - combined with calf symptoms increases suspicion

RSRC_ANKLE_013.text: Do you also have knee pain or have you changed the way you walk recently?
RSRC_ANKLE_013.clinical_note: Proximal compensation - ankle pain secondary to knee pathology

RSRC_ANKLE_014.text: Does your ankle feel unstable or like it might give way?
RSRC_ANKLE_014.clinical_note: Ligamentous laxity - suggests lateral sprain with instability

RSRC_ANKLE_015.clinical_note: Swelling indicates acute injury (sprain) vs chronic/referred pain

RSRC_ANKLE_016.text: Do you feel a burning or electric sensation in your foot?
RSRC_ANKLE_016.clinical_note: Burning/electric = nerve involvement (tarsal tunnel or radiculopathy)

RSRC_ANKLE_017.text: Is your ankle/foot pain worse after sitting for a long time?
RSRC_ANKLE_017.clinical_note: Prolonged sitting worsening = lumbar discogenic referral

RSRC_ANKLE_018.text: Is it painful to put weight on your ankle when walking?
RSRC_ANKLE_018.clinical_note: Weight bearing pain = structural ankle pathology (sprain, fracture)

RSRC_ANKLE_019.text: When you twisted your ankle, was your foot pointed downward (like on tiptoes) or was it flat/bent upward?
RSRC_ANKLE_019.clinical_note: ATFL injured in plantarflexion + inversion; CFL injured in dorsiflexion + inversion

RSRC_ANKLE_020.text: Can you take 4 steps on your injured ankle, even if you have to limp?
RSRC_ANKLE_020.clinical_note: OTTAWA ANKLE RULE: Inability to weight bear 4 steps = X-ray indicated

RSRC_ANKLE_021.text: Is the most tender spot directly ON the ankle bone itself (not beside it)?
RSRC_ANKLE_021.clinical_note: OTTAWA ANKLE RULE: Bone tenderness at posterior edge of lateral malleolus = X-ray indicated

RSRC_ANKLE_022.text: Does it hurt when you try to turn your foot outward against resistance?

RSRC_ANKLE_023.text: Does squeezing your lower leg (calf area) cause pain in your ankle?
RSRC_ANKLE_023.clinical_note: Squeeze test positive = High ankle sprain (syndesmosis)

RSRC_ANKLE_024.text: What is your approximate weight category?
RSRC_ANKLE_024.clinical_note: Underweight=stress fracture risk; Overweight=PTTD, OA risk

RSRC_ANKLE_025.clinical_note: Age affects OA, PTTD, fracture healing, stress fracture risk

RSRC_ANKLE_026.clinical_note: High activity = stress fracture, tendinopathy risk

RSRC_ANKLE_027.text: Have you recently increased your activity level significantly (new exercise program, increased running distance, etc.)?
RSRC_ANKLE_027.clinical_note: Recent increase = high stress fracture risk

RSRC_ANKLE_028.text: Is there tenderness on the INSIDE ankle bone itself (medial malleolus)?
RSRC_ANKLE_028.clinical_note: OTTAWA RULE: Medial malleolus bone tenderness = X-ray required

RSRC_ANKLE_029.text: Is there tenderness on the outside of your foot (base of 5th metatarsal - bony bump halfway down outer foot)?
RSRC_ANKLE_029.clinical_note: OTTAWA RULE: 5th metatarsal tenderness = X-ray required (Jones fracture)

RSRC_ANKLE_030.text: Is there tenderness on the top inner part of your midfoot (navicular bone)?
RSRC_ANKLE_030.clinical_note: OTTAWA RULE: Navicular tenderness = X-ray required (navicular fracture)

RSRC_ANKLE_031.text: Did you notice bruising appear within the first 24 hours?
RSRC_ANKLE_031.clinical_note: Early bruising suggests more significant soft tissue or bone injury

RSRC_ANKLE_032.text: Have you had previous ankle injuries or sprains?
RSRC_ANKLE_032.clinical_note: Previous injury = OA, OCD, chronic instability, sinus tarsi syndrome risk

RSRC_ANKLE_033.text: Has your pain persisted longer than expected after an ankle sprain (more than 6-8 weeks)?
RSRC_ANKLE_033.clinical_note: Persistent pain post-sprain = OCD, sinus tarsi, chronic instability

RSRC_ANKLE_034.text: Does your ankle lock, catch, or click?
RSRC_ANKLE_034.clinical_note: Pathognomonic for OCD (osteochondral lesion) or loose body

RSRC_ANKLE_035.text: Does your pain feel deep inside the ankle joint?
RSRC_ANKLE_035.clinical_note: Deep pain suggests OCD, OA, or intra-articular pathology

RSRC_ANKLE_036.text: Is your pain worse when pointing your toes downward (like a ballet dancer)?

RSRC_ANKLE_037.text: Is your pain worse when bending your ankle upward (dorsiflexion) or squatting deeply?

RSRC_ANKLE_038.text: Do you notice stiffness after sitting that loosens up after a few minutes of walking (less than 30 minutes)?

RSRC_ANKLE_039.text: Is your morning stiffness lasting MORE than 30-60 minutes?
RSRC_ANKLE_039.clinical_note: Prolonged morning stiffness = Inflammatory arthritis (RA, psoriatic)

RSRC_ANKLE_040.text: Do you have similar symptoms in both ankles or other joints?
RSRC_ANKLE_040.clinical_note: Bilateral/multiple joints = Inflammatory or systemic arthritis

RSRC_ANKLE_041.text: Did your pain come on SUDDENLY and SEVERELY (within hours)?
RSRC_ANKLE_041.clinical_note: Sudden severe onset = Gout or septic arthritis

RSRC_ANKLE_042.text: Is your ankle red, hot to touch, and significantly swollen?
RSRC_ANKLE_042.clinical_note: Red/hot/swollen = Gout, septic arthritis, or acute inflammation

RSRC_ANKLE_043.text: Is the pain so severe you cannot tolerate even light touch (like bedsheets)?

RSRC_ANKLE_044.text: Do you have a fever, chills, or feel generally unwell?
RSRC_ANKLE_044.clinical_note: SEPTIC ARTHRITIS RED FLAG - Urgent medical attention required

RSRC_ANKLE_045.text: Have you had similar episodes before that resolved on their own?

RSRC_ANKLE_046.text: Is your pain worse with high-impact activities (running, jumping) but better with rest?

RSRC_ANKLE_047.text: Can you point to one specific spot that is tender to press on (localized bone tenderness)?
RSRC_ANKLE_047.clinical_note: Focal bone tenderness = Stress fracture or bone pathology

RSRC_ANKLE_048.text: Do you have pain along the inner arch of your foot?
RSRC_ANKLE_048.clinical_note: Medial arch pain = PTTD (posterior tibial tendon dysfunction)

RSRC_ANKLE_049.text: Have you noticed your foot becoming flatter over time (acquired flat foot)?

RSRC_ANKLE_050.text: Is it difficult or painful to stand on one leg and rise up onto your toes on the affected side?
RSRC_ANKLE_050.clinical_note: Weak single leg heel raise = PTTD confirmation test

RSRC_ANKLE_051.text: Do you feel grinding or crunching (crepitus) when moving your ankle?

RSRC_ANKLE_052.text: Is your ankle movement range reduced compared to the other side?
RSRC_ANKLE_052.clinical_note: Reduced ROM = OA, impingement, or post-traumatic stiffness

RSRC_ANKLE_053.text: Is there pain in the outer part of your hindfoot/heel area (not the ankle joint itself)?
RSRC_ANKLE_053.clinical_note: Lateral hindfoot pain = Sinus tarsi syndrome

RSRC_ANKLE_054.text: Is your pain worse on uneven ground or when your foot is angled inward/outward?
RSRC_ANKLE_054.clinical_note: Uneven ground pain = Sinus tarsi or subtalar pathology

RSRC_ANKLE_055.text: Are you a dancer, footballer, or do activities requiring pointing your toes frequently?
RSRC_ANKLE_055.clinical_note: Dancers/footballers = Higher risk of posterior impingement

RSRC_ANKLE_056.text: Do you have any family history of arthritis or autoimmune conditions?
RSRC_ANKLE_056.clinical_note: Family history increases inflammatory arthritis risk

RSRC_ANKLE_057.clinical_note: Male=gout risk; Female=stress fracture, PTTD risk

RSRC_ANKLE_058.text: Do you have severe pain at night or pain that wakes you even when not moving?
RSRC_ANKLE_058.clinical_note: Severe rest/night pain = Red flag for infection, tumor, or vascular

RSRC_WRIST_001.text: Does neck position or movement affect your wrist/hand symptoms?

RSRC_WRIST_002.text: Do you have numbness/tingling mainly in your thumb, index, and middle fingers?

RSRC_WRIST_003.text: Are your symptoms worse at night or do they wake you from sleep?

RSRC_WRIST_004.text: Do you have neck, shoulder, or arm symptoms along with your wrist/hand symptoms?

RSRC_WRIST_005.text: Are your symptoms worse with arms overhead or carrying heavy bags on your shoulder?

RSRC_FOOT_001.text: Do you have any lower back or leg pain?

RSRC_FOOT_002.text: Do you have numbness or tingling in your foot following a specific pattern (big toe vs outer foot)?
RSRC_FOOT_002.clinical_note: Big toe = L5, Outer foot = S1

RSRC_FOOT_003.text: Is your pain worst with the first few steps in the morning?

RSRC_FOOT_004.text: Do you have numbness or tingling mainly in the sole of your foot?

referral_questions._comment_knee_enhanced: ========== ENHANCED KNEE SCREENING - HIP AND LUMBAR REFERRAL ==========

RSRC_KNEE_006.text: Is your knee disability WORSE than X-rays suggest? (Using walker/wheelchair despite minor findings)
RSRC_KNEE_006.clinical_note: CRITICAL: Disability > X-ray findings = think HIP referral

RSRC_KNEE_007.text: Does rotating your hip inward cause pain in your groin or hip?
RSRC_KNEE_007.clinical_note: PATHOGNOMONIC for hip OA referring to knee

RSRC_KNEE_008.text: Do you have thigh pain (front or inner thigh) with your knee pain?
RSRC_KNEE_008.clinical_note: Thigh + knee pain = hip referral or L3-L4

RSRC_KNEE_009.text: Did knee treatment (injections, therapy, surgery) fail to help?
RSRC_KNEE_009.clinical_note: Failed knee treatment = reconsider hip as source

RSRC_KNEE_010.text: Does your knee exam seem normal despite significant pain?
RSRC_KNEE_010.clinical_note: Normal knee exam = REFERRED (hip or lumbar)

referral_questions._comment_hip_enhanced: ========== ENHANCED HIP SCREENING - LUMBAR AND VISCERAL ==========

RSRC_HIP_006.text: Does raising your straight leg while lying down cause leg pain?
RSRC_HIP_006.clinical_note: Positive SLR = lumbar radiculopathy, not hip

RSRC_HIP_007.text: Can you move your hip fully without pain when relaxed?
RSRC_HIP_007.clinical_note: Full painless hip ROM = REFERRED (lumbar or SI)

RSRC_HIP_008.text: Do you have numbness or tingling in your leg or foot?

RSRC_HIP_009.text: Is your pain on the SIDE of your hip (over the bony point)?
RSRC_HIP_009.clinical_note: Lateral hip pain = bursitis/gluteal tendinopathy (NOT hip joint)

RSRC_HIP_010.text: Do you have abdominal or pelvic symptoms with your hip pain?
RSRC_HIP_010.clinical_note: RED FLAG: Visceral symptoms = possible referred pain

RSRC_NECK_006.text: Does your neck pain come on with physical exertion or stress?
RSRC_NECK_006.clinical_note: CARDIAC RED FLAG - exertion-related neck pain

RSRC_NECK_007.text: Do you have chest tightness or shortness of breath with neck pain?
RSRC_NECK_007.clinical_note: CARDIAC RED FLAG - chest symptoms with neck pain

RSRC_NECK_008.text: Do you have jaw pain, teeth clenching, or jaw clicking?
RSRC_NECK_008.clinical_note: TMJ dysfunction can refer to neck

RSRC_NECK_009.text: Do you have dizziness when turning your head?

RSRC_NECK_010.text: Do you have arm numbness or tingling from your neck?

RSRC_ELBOW_006.text: Does moving your neck affect your elbow pain?

RSRC_ELBOW_007.text: Do you have thumb/index finger numbness?

RSRC_ELBOW_008.text: Did elbow treatment fail after weeks?

RSRC_ELBOW_009.text: Is your elbow pain bilateral (both sides)?

RSRC_ELBOW_010.text: Do you have ring/little finger numbness?

RSRC_WRIST_006.text: Does moving your neck affect your wrist/hand symptoms?

RSRC_WRIST_007.text: Does raising your arm overhead worsen hand symptoms?

RSRC_WRIST_008.text: Do symptoms wake you at night and improve by shaking your hand?

RSRC_WRIST_009.text: Is numbness in your first 3 fingers (thumb, index, middle)?

RSRC_WRIST_010.text: Is numbness in your last 2 fingers (ring, little)?

RSRC_FOOT_005.text: Do you have lower back pain with your foot symptoms?

RSRC_FOOT_006.text: Do you have difficulty lifting your foot up (foot drop)?
RSRC_FOOT_006.clinical_note: Foot drop = L5 or peroneal neuropathy

RSRC_FOOT_008.text: Do you have calf pain when walking that goes away with rest?

RSRC_FOOT_009.text: Is your foot cold, pale, or has color changes?

RSRC_FOOT_010.text: Do you have burning/tingling in BOTH feet (stocking pattern)?
